newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong's Patten defends Tung on Tory donation.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong's Patten defends Tung on Tory donation.

text.p: Hong Kong Governor Chris Patten on Thursday defended the integrity of his post-colonial successor, Tung Chee-hwa, over allegations that a donation to Britain's Conservative Party in 1992 was politically motivated.
Legislators questioned Patten, who was former Conservative Party chairman, on whether Tung's donation of 50,000 sterling (US$81,500) was a political transaction.
Tung, chosen by a China-assembled committee to run Hong Kong after the British pull out at midnight on June 30, admitted last week he gave the money to the Conservative Party.

"I think it would be a grotesque and wholly unwarranted attack on Mr Tung's integrity to suggest that there was any political transaction as a result of a donation that he made to the Conservative Party," Patten said.
"I don't think that this controversy should be used by anybody to cast wholly unwarranted slurs on the I think unquestioned integrity of the chief executive-designate," he added.
Tung, a former shipping tycoon, plans to ban foreign donations to local political organisation following Hong Kong comes under Chinese rule on July 1.

The donation provoked heavy criticism from Hong Kong's pro-democracy supporters. "It's ridiculous that he is now banning people from doing what he himself has done before," Democratic Party legislator Cheung Man-kwong said.
